repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
**fix(extui): only append messages exceeding 'cmdheight' to "more"**

Problem:  8defe1af declared the "more" window the most convenient place to
          route messages to if it is already open for msg.pos == 'cmd'.
          In usage, this doesn't appear to be the case. Appending messages
          as added in that commit is still useful, but should only be done
          for messages that spill 'cmdheight'.
Solution: Only append messages exceeding 'cmdheight' to the more window.
          To do this, instead of immediately writing to the more buffer,
          write to the cmd buffer and calculate its height. Then copy the
          text and its highlights to the more buffer.

Fix #34372
Fix #34374

**docs(extui): rename box->msg, more->pager, prompt->dialog**

Includes breaking changes to the `opts` layout. "box" doesn't really
describe anything other than a floating window so was an unwanted synonym.

comment_data.body: just for reference: it looks like there is a [`messages` filetype](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/d86d4bacc14bc6ab51b3173f3644d703f53ffbde/runtime/lua/vim/filetype.lua#L2080-L2081) already :(  so we may need to think of a different filetype name for that one. can name it `messages2` (or `mess` or `msg`) and revisit later.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2697,14 +2697,14 @@ There are four separate window types used by this interface:
 • "cmd": The cmdline window; also used for 'showcmd', 'showmode', 'ruler', and
   messages if 'cmdheight' > 0.
 • "box": The message box window; used for messages when 'cmdheight' == 0.
-• "more": The more-prompt window; used for |:messages| and certain messages
-  that should be shown in full.
-• "prompt": The cmdline prompt window; used for prompt messages that expect
-  user input.
-
-These four windows are assigned the "cmdline", "msgbox", "msgmore" and
-"msgprompt" 'filetype' respectively. Use a |FileType| autocommand to configure
-any local options for these windows and their respective buffers.
+• "dialog": The dialog window; used for prompt messages that expect user
+  input.
+• "pager": The pager window; used for |:messages| and certain messages that
+  should be shown in full.
+
+These four windows are assigned the "cmdline", "messages", "dialog" and
+"pager" 'filetype' respectively. Use a |FileType| autocommand to configure any

comment_data.body:
if we rename "box" to `msg` I think it all fits together nicely. then we could use `filetype=msg` too.

```suggestion
  for _, type in ipairs({ 'msg', 'cmd', 'pager', 'dialog' }) do
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -33,7 +33,7 @@ local tab = 0
 --- Ensure the various buffers and windows have not been deleted.
 function M.tab_check_wins()
   local curtab = api.nvim_get_current_tabpage()
-  for _, type in ipairs({ 'box', 'cmd', 'more', 'prompt' }) do
+  for _, type in ipairs({ 'box', 'cmd', 'pager', 'dialog' }) do

comment_data.body:
Could work but in that case we should probably also rename the `cfg.msg.pos == 'box'` config we already have for it, which then becomes a bit nondescript. Still OK as long as its documented it I guess. Either messages go the the cmdline or to a dedicated messages window.

I actually don't think we want "box" in the documentation at all, as it's just a synonym for a floating window. So I also removed the box field from the config table.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -33,7 +33,7 @@ local tab = 0
 --- Ensure the various buffers and windows have not been deleted.
 function M.tab_check_wins()
   local curtab = api.nvim_get_current_tabpage()
-  for _, type in ipairs({ 'box', 'cmd', 'more', 'prompt' }) do
+  for _, type in ipairs({ 'box', 'cmd', 'pager', 'dialog' }) do

comment_data.body:
Is this a typo? `ext.wins.cmd` -> `ext.wins.pager`

Something broken with this:
```
nvim --clean --cmd "lua require('vim._extui').enable({})" +"com" --cmd "lua vim.defer_fn(function() vim.api.nvim_input('g<lt>w*') end, 100)"
```
```
Lua: /home/phan/b/neovim/runtime/lua/vim/_extui/messages.lua:96: Line index out of bounds
stack traceback:
               [C]: in function 'nvim_win_text_height'
               /home/phan/b/neovim/runtime/lua/vim/_extui/messages.lua:96: in function 'set_virttext'
               /home/phan/b/neovim/runtime/lua/vim/_extui/messages.lua:414: in function 'handler'
               /home/phan/b/neovim/runtime/lua/vim/_extui.lua:47: in function 'ui_callback'
               /home/phan/b/neovim/runtime/lua/vim/_extui.lua:82: in function </home/phan/b/neovim/runtime/lua/vim/_extui.lua:78>
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -296,8 +296,9 @@ function M.show_msg(tar, content, replace_last, append, more)
       api.nvim__redraw({ flush = true, cursor = true, win = ext.wins.cmd })
     else
       local h = api.nvim_win_text_height(ext.wins.cmd, {})
-      if (more or not api.nvim_win_get_config(ext.wins.cmd).hide) and h.all > ext.cmdheight then
-        msg_to_more(tar)
+      local want_pager = pager or will_pager or not api.nvim_win_get_config(ext.wins.pager).hide

comment_data.body:
No, I changed it because the 'cmd' seemed to have been a typo. I'll look into the error (which would be avoided if the `:command` had the `list_cmd` kind, which it should, but need to resolve this regardless).

I guess I'll start adding regression tests for stuff like this that's unlikely to be covered by the current test suite even if extui is made default.

```
nvim --clean --cmd "lua require('vim._extui').enable({})" +com +ls
```

comment_regular_data.body:
type `:ls`, `:q`, `:com`:
```
vim.schedule callback: /home/phan/b/neovim/runtime/lua/vim/_extui/messages.lua:193: Invalid 'end_col': out of range
stack traceback:
	[C]: in function 'nvim_buf_set_extmark'
	/home/phan/b/neovim/runtime/lua/vim/_extui/messages.lua:193: in function </home/phan/b/neovim/runtime/lua/vim/_extui/messages.lua:183>
```

Two behaviors different from builtin one:

`:echo 1 2`
<details>

builtin:
```
1 2
```
extui:
```
1
2
```
</details>

`:echon 1 2`, `g<`

<details>

builtin:
```
12
```

extui:
```
1
2
```
</details>

`nvim --clean --cmd "lua require('vim._extui').enable({})" +"echo globpath(&rtp, '*') | com"`
```
vim.schedule callback: /home/phan/b/neovim/runtime/lua/vim/_extui/messages.lua:255: Invalid 'end_col': out of range
stack traceback:
	[C]: in function 'nvim_buf_set_text'
	/home/phan/b/neovim/runtime/lua/vim/_extui/messages.lua:255: in function 'show_msg'
	/home/phan/b/neovim/runtime/lua/vim/_extui/messages.lua:378: in function 'handler'
	/home/phan/b/neovim/runtime/lua/vim/_extui.lua:50: in function 'fn'
	/home/phan/b/neovim/runtime/lua/vim/_editor.lua:367: in function </home/phan/b/neovim/runtime/lua/vim/_editor.lua:366>
```

> Two behaviors different from builtin one:

Fixed by #34393

> nvim --clean --cmd "lua require('vim._extui').enable({})" +"echo globpath(&rtp, '*') | com"

Thanks I'll look into it.

This now also addresses #34372, and https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/34373#discussion_r2134845380. I went with a dot instead of a hyphen for the buffer name to continue the convention set for augroups/namespaces, or is there a reason a hyphen is better for buffer names @justinmk?

Let's also rename the more window to "pager" here, I think that makes more sense as a buffer name. It's more universally recognized, and it's already a synonym for `:h more-prompt`.

> I went with a dot instead of a hyphen for the buffer name to continue the convention set for augroups/namespaces, or is there a reason a hyphen is better for buffer names

For a URI scheme, a dot might be strange since it looks like a TLDN? In general, a URI-like name seems like a good practice. It allows us to clearly namespace names that are owned by Nvim. (`nvim://...`, `nvim-pager://...`)

> Let's also rename the more window to "pager" here, I think that makes more sense as a buffer name.

Yeah. "more" is a historical detail. I don't see "pager" in the current PR diff though.

> For a URI scheme, a dot might be strange since it looks like a TLDN? In general, a URI-like name seems like a good practice. It allows us to clearly namespace names that are owned by Nvim. (nvim://..., nvim-pager://...)

Yeah I was just thinking of this as a ('buftype' = "nofile") identifier for wherever it shows up. Not familiar with how or where having a clearly defined URI for this would help, but happy to oblige.

If we only ever have 1 pager buffer, and we don't plan to have path-like or querystring-like parameters in the URI, then claiming a simple name like `[Pager]` can work (similar to `[Scratch]`).

But if we may have more than 1 pager buffer, disambiguating buffer names via URI syntax is very helpful and harmonious with vim's buffer system. (Example: `fugitive://...` buffers.)

Ah yes good point, I think the `[]` special buffer recipe might be good to follow for these buffers. Would have to prefix `Message` for the message buffer (so `[Message <Box, Pager, Prompt>]`), because `[Prompt]` already exists for the prompt 'buftype'.

And `[Command Line]` is (unfortunately) used for the command line window. Not sure whether we can change that to `[Command Window]` (BWC), or what else to name the cmdline buffer just so that it doesn't conflict with that (`[Cmd]`, `[Cmdline]`).

> prefix `Message` for the message buffer (so `[Message <Box, Pager, Prompt>]`), because `[Prompt]` already exists for the prompt 'buftype'.

- `[Pager]` is too good to pass up, let's stick with that :)
- The "Box" could be named `[Messages]` (and we can use that for the ["Phase 2" overlay](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/34281) too).
- Is the "Prompt" for things like `inputlist()`? Could be named `[Dialog]` or something, we can revisit later.

> Not sure whether we can change that to `[Command Window]`

we could try it, but probably not worth the trouble.

> or what else to name the cmdline buffer just so that it doesn't conflict with that (`[Cmd]`, `[Cmdline]`).

either sounds good

Good suggestions, I think. Also using those for the 'filetype' then.

> The "Box" could be named [Messages] (and we can use that for the https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/34281 too).

Your phase 2 suggestion would probably make more sense to route to the dialog buffer, both conceptually and functionally. (I have yet to try this, not sure I'm a fan of it or if it will work out. Also not sure a new option is necessary. If it disappears on any input, lets just show the full message.)

> Is the "Prompt" for things like inputlist()?

Yeah, it's a temporary window opened for messages received before a cmdline prompt that looks similar to the pager but isn't entered.

> Maybe msg_history_show need a append for each entry:

Yes I think that would make sense👍🏻

Added on top of this in #34467

title: fix(extui): only append messages exceeding 'cmdheight' to "more"
